label: Minard's Map of Napoleon's March
creator: Charles Minard
description: Charles Minard's visualization depicting Napoleon's march on Moscow
pedagogical_description: Good example of making choices about what and how to visualize, including removing superfluous elements
data_type: 1 or more categorical variables|1 or more numerical variables|1 or more date/time variables|1 or more geospatial variables

label: Gun Deaths in Florida
creator: C.Chan
description: Visualization of the number of gun deaths in Florida from 1990-2013
pedagogical_description: Demonstrates the power of visual encoding to make the visualization harder to interpret. The creator tried to use the metaphor of dripping blood and flipped the y-axis but it's easier to see the rise in gun deaths when the y-axis is in the more traditional direction. Flipped version of the chart is later in the article.

label: built : Los Angeles
creator: Andy Rutkowski
description: This visualization shows every building in Los Angeles County mapped by the year in which it was built. The example is aimed at showing how open source tools such as QGIS, Leaflet, and Mapbox might be used to visualize open data.
pedagogical_description: Location based example that draws people in because housing is so important in Los Angeles. Shows the development of Los Angeles via building data which is freely available.
ethical_quandries: This dataset is a great way for people to think about development, access to housing, and issues in urban studies.
data_type: 1 or more date/time variables|1 or more geospatial variables

label: Casualties of the Iraq War
creator: Simon Scarr
description:
A visualization of casualties of the Iraq war. From the creator: "This graphic was created to mark the end of the United States' military engagement in Iraq in 2011. Over 4,800 coalition soldiers and tens of thousands of Iraqis lost their lives in the war.

One deliberate design choice with this graphic was the visual metaphor of blood. This striking visual would hopefully draw the reader into the graphic."
pedagogical_description: Data visualization tells a story. Emotional
ethical_quandries: Questions about representation (e.g. who is represented and who is not represented?). Issues of spatial aggregation in the map (How do casualty count port to troop population size? Can we know if one area was more dangerous than another?)

label: Water Use in the U.S.
creator: USGS VIZLAB
description: A compilation of data visualizations about water use in the U.S. in 2015, based on data from the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) National Water Use Science Project.
pedagogical_description: Example data visualizations are presented with corresponding dataset and code linked on the page, programming and data visualizations created using GitHub and Java, Jenkins, CSS, Docker, Rstudio/R, data visualizations can be recreated from data using multiple tools/programs and compared with original source and include examples of design principles and best practices in use.
linked_instr_mtl: Code and accompanying dataset available on GitHub - https://github.com/USGS-VIZLAB/water-use-15 and in report/circular -  https://pubs.er.usgs.gov/publication/cir1441
data_type: 1 or more categorical variables|1 or more numerical variables|1 or more date/time variables|1 or more geospatial variables
vis_type: bar chart|pie chart or donut chart|map / spatial data|interactive quiz; mixed map and pie chart

label: Legislative Explorer
creator: John Wilkerson and Rohnin Randles
description: Visualization to see the legislative process from start to finish. Follow from bills to law. Has options for the United States and for Washington (state).
pedagogical_description: Value of being able to filter, use of a timeline
ethical_quandries: Transparency -- links to the original bills so that users can read about it further. But how would they handle representing bipartisan legislation? Also, uncertain if this visualization is web accessible.
data_type: 1 or more categorical variables|1 or more numerical variables|1 or more date/time variables
